==Explanation==
This comic is about the difficulty of dealing psychologically with 50/50 odds and is likely inspired by the {{w|2024 United States presidential election}}. This comic was released the day before Election Day, and the media had been reporting (based off of voter polls) that the two presidential candidates, [[Kamala Harris]] and [[Donald Trump]], were closely contesting for the White House. The odds of the election were close to 50/50, including sources such as [https://www.270towin.com/2024-presidential-election-polls/ 270 to Win], [https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/polls-president.html/ the New York Times], and [https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/ FiveThirtyEight]. It seems more people suffer from [https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/04/us/politics/election-anxiety.html/ pre-election] [https://fortune.com/well/article/election-anxiety/ anxiety], and the uncertainty of the results doesn't help.

Furthermore, with regards to N/A - the odds of "precisely" 50/50 are probabilistically zero, unless the event under consideration is something relatively trivial such as a coinflip or die roll (and even with those it is extremely unlikely the coins or dice are perfectly "fair").  Any scenario that involves social sciences, such as an election (or even a single relationship) will never be precisely 50/50 (or, indeed, *any* discrete value).

| Precisely 50/50 || ????? N/A ???? || {{w|N/A}} stands for "not available", "no answer", "not applicable" or "not assessed". The actual worst case scenario, with no single obvious stance to take. (Thus also leaving ambiguous which fall-back position one should prepare to hold in reserve.)
|}

The title text is a joke making use of ambiguous wording: "researchers who are experts in emotional spirals" could either refer to researchers who study emotional spirals, or researchers who are undergoing emotional spirals themselves. Evidently, all the researchers "we" contacted were the latter, and thus unable to advise the comic.

Randall had previously dealt with the possibility of a tied electoral count 12 years prior, in the ''[[what if? (blog)|what if?]]'' article ''{{what if|19|Tie Vote}}
